description:
Latin (1587) Septuagint - Vetus Testamentum Iuxta Septuaginta

The Roman Septuagint, also known as the Sixtine Septuagint or Roman Sixtine Septuagint, is an edition of the Septuagint published in 1587, commissioned by Pope Sixtus V. Although completed in 1586, it wasn't published until May 1587, with a second 'I' often added to the publication date in many copies. This edition is notably based on the Codex Vaticanus and its text became the standard for most subsequent Septuagint editions for three centuries, until superseded by Rahlf's edition.

Antonio Carafa oversaw the creation of the Roman Septuagint, published by Sixtus V's authority to aid the revisers working on the Latin Vulgate edition mandated by the Council of Trent. This edition played a crucial role in biblical scholarship and the standardization of biblical texts during a significant period in the history of Christian theology and the development of Western biblical studies.
